intro: Caragana pygmaea lusus brevifolia, commonly known as the dwarf shrub willow, is a small, deciduous shrub native to the arctic and alpine regions of North America. It typically grows to a height of 10–30 centimeters, featuring dense, wiry branches and small, oval leaves that are often covered in a fine layer of white hair. The plant produces yellow flowers in early summer, which are clustered in elongated, drooping inflorescences. Its root system is extensive and helps stabilize soil in harsh environments. Caragana pygmaea lusus brevifolia is adapted to cold climates and is often found in tundra and rocky habitats.
